Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Nutrients and Energy-rich Macromolecules Recovery from Microalgae using Subcritical Water

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1351413
Kumar

In this CAREER research/educational project, the PI will utilize subcritical water for both extracting the energy-rich macromolecules and for recovering the minerals. The project is expected the address both of the challenges currently faced by algae biofuels. In the first step, PI will utilize flash hydrolysis (FH) to recover proteins, carbohydrates, lipids. In the second step, the PI will utilize hydrothermal mineralization (HTM) to recover inorganic nutrients for recycling. The proposed process has potential of recovering more than two-thirds of macronutrients using geo-mimetic precipitation method, while producing biofuel intermediate species. These nutrients include P, N, and inorganic solids. The FH process has the advantage of being able to disrupt algal cell walls without changing the functionality of the cell components such as lipids. The recovered nutrients will be utilized as slow-release fertilizer for algae cultivation. An array of characterization methods will be utilized for understanding the effects of algae productivity, and the efficacy of the recycled nutrients.

Selective FH of algae proteins within a few seconds without the use of any added chemicals is a new concept. The project will examine FH of model proteins to derive a fundamental understanding of reaction pathways, intermediate compounds, and interactions of macromolecules under fast reaction conditions. This will extend our knowledge of conversion of organic matters in hydrothermal medium. The proposed nutrients recovery using HTM mimics natural geological process of minerals precipitation in aqueous medium. The integration of HTM with FH is a novel concept considering that no additional heating or pressurization will be required. A new knowledge will be developed by studying the mineralization and precipitation of dissolved ionic species (extracted from algae during FH) in hydrothermal medium to recover nutrients. The additional benefits include production of biofuel intermediates while reducing NOx emissions.

In addition to educating graduate and undergraduate students, the project calls for K-12 and community outreach and involvement of underrepresented/minority groups. The outreach program is supplemented and enhanced by laboratory experiences. The PI also aims to introduce a freshman level class of environmental sustainability, exposing students to the importance and career possibilities in this topic area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new process termed ‘Flash Hydrolysis’ was developed for processing algae for biofuels and bioproducts. Flash hydrolysis process for algae is conducted in a continuous flow reactor under subcritical water medium for a short (~10 seconds) residence time. The new process demonstrated a way of extracting proteins from algae in aqueous phase while preserving lipids in solid phase. The extracted proteins in aqueous phase was used for several applications such as direct nutrients (nitrogen & phosphorous) recycling for cultivating algae, producing polyol which was used in polyurethane preparation, peptides and amino acid production, struvite synthesis as a slow-release fertilizer, and hydroxyapatite (used in artificial bone) production via hydrothermal mineralization process. The solid fraction recovered after Flash Hydrolysis was rich in lipids. This solid was evaluated for ease of lipid extraction using organic solvent (hexane) and was subjected to hydrothermal liquefaction for biocrude production. Overall, the Flash Hydrolysis process is an environmentally-benign process which is conducted in subcritical water medium and can be applied to other organic feedstock for extracting high-value products. A private industry and a national lab are interested in the Flash Hydrolysis of algae and has entered into sponsored research project recently.

A total of 8 PhD students and 4 Master students participated (partly or fully) in this project. Besides graduate students, more than 30 Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) students participated in this project and got trained in several technical skills and laboratory instruments. The principal investigator (PI) developed a 4-week summer ‘Biofuels Research Apprentice Program (B-RAP)’ for the local high school students under this project. More than 25 local high school students participated and got trained. An informative video and a website (https://www.odubiofuelslab.org/grants) was prepared for the outreach purpose. The PI has included the research finding in in graduate course ‘Biofuels Engineering’ and an undergraduate course ‘Introduction to Sustainable Chemistry and Engineering’

Two patent applications were filed under this project. A total of 15 peer-reviewed publications in reputed journals and more than 41 conference presentations were prepared for the project dissemination and publishing the new findings. The PI has written a book on the topic ‘Sub- and Supercritical Hydrothermal Technology: Industrial Applications’ which is under review for the publication.
